channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Science Fuels the Writing, and Faith, of a Nicaraguan Poet
item.description: To honor the long life of Ernesto Cardenal, a Roman Catholic priest and a revolutionary, the writer Sergio Ramírez compiled an anthology of Father Cardenal’s poems: “Ninety at Ninety.”
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH MALKIN
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Science brings me close to God because it describes the universe and creation, and that brings me close to the creator.” — The Rev. Ernesto Cardenal

item.title: Serge Hochar, Producer of Lebanese Wines, Dies at 75
item.description: Mr. Hochar made his Chateau Musar much admired, in part for having operated even as civil war raged in Lebanon.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC ASIMOV
item.media:credit: Sasha Maslov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Serge Hochar crisscrossed six continents promoting his long-lived wines, as well as the ancient wine culture of Lebanon.

item.title: Two Big Pieces of AirAsia Jet Are Found; Search Crews Have Recovered 46 Bodies
item.description: Officials said that they had identified three of the bodies, but that stormy seas had prevented them from deploying sophisticated sonar equipment.
item.dc:creator: By TOM MCCAWLEY
item.media:description: Workers unloaded coffins Friday for the victims of AirAsia Flight 8501 in Pangkalan Bun, Indonesia, close to the site where wreckage from the airliner was discovered.

item.title: A Ring Sparks Speculation That North Korean Leader’s Sister Has Married
item.description: A photograph in a North Korean newspaper of Kim Jong-un’s younger sister wearing what may be a wedding ring has prompted suggestions that she recently married the son of one of Mr. Kim’s close aides.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: More Sanctions on North Korea After Sony Case
item.description: The Obama administration doubled down on its allegation that North Korea’s leadership was behind the hacking of Sony Pictures.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT

item.title: World Briefing: West Bank: Settlers Throw Stones at American Consular Officials
item.description: Jewish settlers threw stones at American consular officials on Friday during a visit the officials made to the West Bank, Israeli police and Palestinian witnesses said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Hong Kong Slaughters Chickens After an Outbreak of Bird Flu
item.description: Hong Kong health officials have slaughtered thousands of chickens from mainland China and closed markets, after tests found some birds were infected with a strain of bird flu.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: As Refugee Tide Swells, Lebanon Plans a Visa Requirement for Syrians
item.description: Some 1.1 million Syrians are said to have sought refuge in Lebanon, a nation of four million people.
item.category: United Nations High Commission for Refugees
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: A father, center, and some of his 14 children bundled up against an icy rain in an unofficial refugee camp in Lebanon. The family fled Raqqa Province in Syria.

item.title: In Sweden, the Land of the Open Door, Anti-Muslim Sentiment Finds a Foothold
item.description: Amid the relentless stream of migrants to Europe that has fueled a backlash against immigrants, directed most viciously at Muslims, arson is suspected at mosques in three Swedish cities over the last 10 days.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY
item.media:credit: Alexander Mahmoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: Khalif Samantar, right, an immigrant from Somalia, jumped out a window to escape from a burning mosque in Eskilstuna, Sweden, on Christmas Day.

item.title: Saudi King, 90, Hospitalized; Pneumonia Is Diagnosed
item.description: The king’s health is scrutinized for any hint of a leadership change in Saudi Arabia, a top oil producer and American ally.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: When Celebrity Fortunetellers Talk, the Lebanese Listen
item.description: In a region where many governments criminalize divination, Lebanon stands apart for featuring its star soothsayers on New Year’s Eve, when they make predictions in TV specials.
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
item.media:credit: Andrew McConnell for The New York Times
item.media:description: Leila Abdel Latif preparing to go on air at LBC studios in Jounieh, Lebanon, on New Year’s Eve, when she makes predictions about the year ahead.

item.title: World Briefing: Cuba: Performance Artist Is Freed
item.description: The Cuban performance artist Tania Bruguera was released from custody on Friday after her third arrest this week related to her efforts to push for freedom of expression.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

item.title: Opinion: Suicides Spread Through a Brazilian Tribe
item.description: After losing their way of life, some indigenous people lose hope.
item.dc:creator: By CHARLES LYONS

item.title: India Says Men on Pakistani Boat Set Off Explosion in Arabian Sea
item.description: Pakistan denies the Indian Defense Ministry’s account of intercepting a suspicious Pakistan-based boat in the Arabian Sea.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Traffickers Set Freighter on a Course for Italy and Flee, Leaving Migrants Aboard
item.description: The Italian Coast Guard said the cargo ship, carrying about 450 migrants, was being towed toward the southeastern coast after running out of fuel.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: The Ezadeen, a merchant ship with 450 migrants on board, off the southern coast of Italy, near Crotone, on Friday.

item.title: Argentina Agrees to Extradite American Who Sought Asylum
item.description: Kurt Sonnenfeld claims that he is being framed for his wife’s death to discredit his theories about government foreknowledge of the Sept. 11 attacks.
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN GILBERT
item.media:credit: John Prieto/The Denver Post, via Associated Press

item.title: Unruly Factions Hurt Taliban’s Bid to Capture Afghan Hearts, and Territory
item.description: Factions of the movement have hardened, while others are involved in kidnappings, robberies and the opium trade — damaging the Taliban’s efforts to win over the Afghan population.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED
item.media:description: A government building stormed by Taliban fighters in Jalalabad in May, part of a season of significant Taliban military gains across Afghanistan.

item.title: Palestinians Submit Papers to U.N. to Join International Criminal Court
item.description: The court could potentially investigate serious crimes on Palestinian lands committed by either side in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Historical Drama Shows Too Much Cleavage for China’s Censors
item.description: “The Empress of China” was pulled briefly from the air, but when it returned it was clear that the show’s aesthetic had undergone a major transformation: The ample chests that once filled the screen were nowhere to be seen.
item.dc:creator: By AMY QIN
item.media:description: An 18th century painting of the Empress Wu Zetian.

item.title: In Moments, New Year’s Revelry Became Fatal Crush in Shanghai
item.description: Most of the 36 victims were young revelers who had come to ring in 2015 on the Bund, the city’s iconic riverfront promenade.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID BARBOZA
item.media:description: Revelers caught in a stampede during a New Year’s Eve celebration on the Bund, a waterfront promenade in Shanghai.
